awd_titl_txt: Picowatt-Resolution Calorimetry for Probing Near-Field Radiative Thermal Transport
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET-1235691
Sangi Reddy

A major challenge for the 21th century, across diverse fields of engineering and science, is to precisely understand how energy is transported and converted at the nanoscale, with the ultimate goal of harnessing conversion and transport mechanisms for the development of a wide range of novel technologies, including sustainable energy generation. While radiative thermal transport between macroscopic objects separated by large distances is well understood, radiative heat transfer in the near-field the regime in which the spacing between two surfaces is smaller than the peak wavelength predicted by Wien?s displacement law?is poorly understood. This lack of knowledge is primarily due to experimental challenges in performing accurate, quantitative measurements of near-field radiative heat transport. 

This proposal seeks to overcome critical obstacles to near-field radiative heat transport experiments and develop a sensitive, picowatt-resolution calorimetry based, experimental platform to provide the first quantitative measurements of near field radiative heat transfer between parallel surfaces with nanoscale gaps. Further, the experimental approaches developed in this work will enable the utilization of near-field effects to probe DC heat output of microscopic systems with unprecedented resolution. 

The techniques and tools that will be developed as part of this work will significantly enrich the field of micro/nanoscale energy transport where the lack of experimental tools to probe near-field radiative transport is a major impediment to progress. Further, this work will enable several other applications such as near-field enabled nanopatterning, and novel metrology measurements. In the long term, the proposed development of near-field enabled DC picowatt resolution calorimetry can have a transformative effect on the study of complex biological systems, particularly individual cells, and give us a wealth of information that can not be obtained through other means. In addition to addressing the technical questions described above, the proposal also incorporates extensive outreach activities to engage undergraduate and graduate students as well as underrepresented minorities in research. Toward this goal the PIs will: 1) recruit three undergraduate students per year for research training, 2) develop a graduate class on near-field thermal transport, 3) incorporate research results and novel heat transfer phenomena into an undergraduate lab class taught by the PIs, and 4) create an educational video based on our research for broader dissemination.

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this project was to develop the instrumentation required to probe near-field radiative thermal transport. Specifically, we sought to leverage novel scanning probes, nano calorimeters  and custom-built nano postponers to systematically study near-field radiative heat transfer.

Intellectual Merit: This work led to several breakthroughs. In a first set of experiments we showed that near-field thermal transport properties can be dramatically enhanced by even nanometer-sized thin films if the gap size between the hot and cold surfaces is comparable to the thickness of the films. We came to this important conclusion based on both experiments performed using the novel instrumentation developed in the projects as well as detailed theoretical analysis which showed that the penetration depth of cavity surface phonon polaritons (which are the dominant contributors to near-field radiative transport) is strongly dependent on the gap size. These results we  published in Nature Nanotechnology in 2015 (B. Song et al., Nat. Nanotechnology, 2015).

In a second set of experiments we probed thermal radiation in few nanometer-sized gaps. In this work we leveraged custom built scanning probes with embedded thermocouples and studied radiative heat transfer in gaps ranging from 2 nm to 50 nm between metal and dielectric surfaces. These experiments revealed that radiative heat transfer, even in few nm sized gaps, can be modeled accurately using current theories of thermal radiation (fluctuational electrodynamics). Given the importance and novelty of these results they were published in Nature in 2015. (K. Kim et al., Nature, 2015)

In a third set of experiments we obtained the first detailed measurements of radiative heat transfer between planar surfaces coated with polar dielectrics or metals (Au) and showed that the radiative heat transfer in nanoscale gaps is dramatically enhanced. These results show for the first time that predictions based on fluctuational electrodynamics are in reasonable agreement with experimental results. These results were also published in Nature Nanotechnology in 2016 (B. Song et al., Nat. Nanotechnology, 2016)

Broader Impact: In order to integrate our research results and into the university’s teaching curriculum we have made extensive changes to a Mechanical Engineering undergraduate, senior laboratory course (ME 495), to included modern concepts and experimental approaches to nanoscale heat transfer. Leveraging our NSF-funded work we were able to obtain significant internal funding from the College of Engineering and purchased four atomic force microscopes (from AFM Workshop, http://www.afmworkshop.com). Two of the PIs (Reddy and Meyhofer) spent well in excess of 100 hours each in 2013 to successfully develop new lab modules where nanoscale metrology is introduced to a large number of undergraduate students (~100 per semester). These lab modules were introduced for the first time by the PIs in Fall 2013 and are being taught again now in Fall 2014. Using these AFMs students are now performing experiments to understand data storage in digital media such as DVDs and CDs, they also perform experiments to examine the flexural rigidity of a biopolymer, microtubules, and finally they learn about the origin of Brownian noise and methods to quantitatively characterize such noise by computing the power spectral density. In addition, one of the PIs (Pramod Reddy) has developed a graduate course on nanoscale radiative heat transfer and taught in Winter 2015 for the first time. Further, we have actively encouraged undergraduate students and women in the masters program to actively participate in research in our groups.
